label: america1777
description: Steve's allegorical painting is a commentary on and companion to the once well-known national icon, "The Murder of Jane McCrae," painted by John Vanderlyn in 1804. Her killing in 1777 was one of the events (along with the so-called Wyoming Valley and Cherry Valley massacres of 1778) that created an atmosphere in which the Sullivan-Clinton Campaign against Iroquoia was launched in 1779.

label: Indian Time 1
medium: Acrylic watches, faces printed with Peter Rindisbacher imagery, birch log, logo label
description: An installation consisting of a display of contemporary acrylic watches printed with imagery taken from the work of Swiss pioneer artist Peter Rindisbacher. Their design and production, including the "Chippewatch" logo, was the artist's contribution to the 1996 Swiss Institute exhibition Red River Crossings: Contemporary Native American Artists Respond to Peter Rindisbacher (1806-1834).

label: Wyoming Massacre
description: The most common historical image (19th century) of the killings of July 3, 1778 in the Wyoming Valley. Today, the Pennsyl- vania Historical and Museum Commission holds there was a bloody defeat, but no general massacre afterwards.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: Immediate Retaliation
description: In September 1778, Col. Thomas Hartley led over 200 troops against the region's Haudeno- saunee and Delware villages, to avenge the July defeat and bloody aftermath in the Wyoming Valley.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: Hartley's Revenge
description: American Col. Hartley's Expedition is remember -ed by this 1929 plaque for having burned Teoga and Queen Esther's Town. It was another turn in a brutal cycle of reciprocal violence against Settler and Indian villages on the Wild East frontier.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: Once A Crossroads
description: Markers on Rt, 220 note where Indian villages of Teoga & Queen Esther's Town stood before September 1791 and Hartley's Expedition burned them out.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: The Setting
description: The Fenimore Museum sits on Lake Otsego as it flows (at you) into the Susquehanna River. In 1779, these waters bore Clinton's flotilla to join Sullivan at Iroquoia's edge. With Indians gone, Lake Otsego became J.F. Cooper's "Glimmerglass," and today it ports Baseball's Hall of Fame.
curatorial_notes: Searing visions of Sullivan/Clinton by Haudenosaunee Artists at the 5th Iroquois Biennial Art Exhibition, curated by Peter Jemison, at the Fenimore Museum in Cooperstown, NY (ended 12/31/05)

label: Back to the Present
description: The Fenimore Museum, with courage, is the responsible host of present-day Haudeno- saunee renderings and responses - in painting, sculpture, ceramics and video - to the Sullivan/ Clinton Campaign. (Courtesy of The Fenimore Museum)
curatorial_notes: Searing visions of Sullivan/Clinton by Haudenosaunee Artists at the 5th Iroquois Biennial Art Exhibition, curated by Peter Jemison, at the Fenimore Museum in Cooperstown, NY (ended 12/31/05)

label: Across the Threshold
description: In the exhibit space, visitors will encounter an interactive map, where children and parents can sit & learn about Sullivan/Clinton, and/or go straight on to encounter the compelling images throughout...
curatorial_notes: Searing visions of Sullivan/Clinton by Haudenosaunee Artists at the 5th Iroquois Biennial Art Exhibition, curated by Peter Jemison, at the Fenimore Museum in Cooperstown, NY (ended 12/31/05)

label: america1777
description: Steve's allegorical painting is a commentary on and companion to the once well-known national icon, "The Murder of Jane McCrae," painted by John Vanderlyn in 1804. Her killing in 1777 was one of the events (along with the so-called Wyoming Valley and Cherry Valley massacres of 1778) that created an atmosphere in which the Sullivan-Clinton Campaign against Iroquoia was launched in 1779.

label: The Death of Jane McCrea
description: Eric v.d. Luft describes the painting as "a classic depiction of American attitudes toward Indian savagery," in his "Mcrae, Jane" entry for the _Encyclopedia of New York State_ edited by Peter Eisenstadt and published by Syracuse University Press, 2005, pp. 963.
curatorial_notes: Size: Height: 82.5 cm X Width: 67.3 cm

label: Clearing Darkness: The First Condolence
description:
"It is said that there once was a time in our (Haudenosaunee) history where the people (Onkwehonweh) came to forget the original instructions given to them by Sonkwaiatison (the Creator of all Things). During this time, the five nations of the Haudenosaunee (Seneca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, Mohawk) waged war against one another, and much destruction evolved from acts of revenge, violence, and even hatred. The respect and gratitude for life which had been taught to them by their creator had been lost. As Sonkwaiatison watched their actions with a heavy heart, he decided to send a messenger to earth remind these people of his teachings and return (restore) peace to their hearts, minds, and daily lives.

  Soon a child was born on earth whose life purpose would be to restore peace and unity to the lives of the Haudenosaunee. He was know as the Peacemaker and, despite the things that were going on in life around him, he continued to walk upon the earth with a good heart and a good mind as he grew into manhood. Because he was honest and pure of spirit, it was said that the light always shown upon his face. Many people, however, did not understand the message of peace that he carried, so he decided that it was time to leave his place of birth to seek out those who would understand and embrace the peace that he had to offer.

  During his travels, he came upon a man who was stricken seven times over with grief, living alone in the forest. He acknowledged the man's grief and asked him why he was living alone, away from those who could console him. The man replied, "Some evil sorcery has been used to take the lives of my seven daughters. In all my misery and sorrow, I became bitter and enraged. Carrying my dark shroud of grief and misery, I thought it best to cast myself away from my people."

  The Peacemaker then acknowledged the shell strings this man, known as Aionwatha, had compiled. He grasped them gently and said, "I will use these strings you have carefully created to remove the grief and sorrow from your mind. Some of these strings will be used to set your mind straight so that it can rest once again. Others will be used to wipe the tears from your eyes so that you can once again see things clearly as they are. The strings that remain will be used to remove the cries of sorrow from your ears so that you can hear things clearly once again. In the future, these shell strings shall be used in this way to console others who have lost their loved ones to death's grasp. Do you accept my condolences?"

  In accepting the Peacemaker's words, Aionwatha's grief was lifted and peace was restored to him once again. He stood, and together they collaborated to carry this message of peace to all others who would listen.

  This painting depicts that first meeting between the Peacemaker and Aionwatha, where the first condolence took place.
"
curatorial_notes: Cost $3000

label: Boyd-Parker Park 2
description: Commemorates the martyrdom of the two Yankee scouts at the hands of Iroquois captors. Boyd led 28 scouts in a search for Little Beard's Town, which is burned on September 14, the day their corpses are found by Sullivan's troops.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: Driven from Home
description: The flight of 5,000+ Haudenosaunee refugees from Sullivan's advance in September, 1779. (Print of Ernest Smith's 1936 watercolor.)
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: Little Beard's Town Map
description: The Seneca capital, at the Western Door, was S/C's prime target. It is where Boyd & Parker were captured and killed while trying to locate the town for burning.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: Little Beards Town Marker
description: The back of theS/C monument in Boyd- Parker Park is the only outdoor indication of the former site of the Seneca capital, the once West- ern Door, burnt by Sullivan/Clinton on Sept. 14, 1779.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: At The Border
description: Jemison's painting depicts the schism imposed on Indians by nation state borders. Casting blood red shadows, the two crows facing each other symbolize both division and bonds between Canadian and U.S. Iroquois communities. Their separation was partly created by the Sullivan-Clinton Campaign.

label: Karmic Justice?
description: A nearby salt mine collapse in 1994 caused this toxic sinkhole. It festers with methane emissions, at the center of the former Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, destroyed by Sullivan/Clinton.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: The Bitter Waters
description: The collapse and flooding of the old Retsof mine shafts created this toxic sink hole. It lies beneath the Geneseo- Cuylerville road bridge, only 50 yards from Boyd-Parker Park, at the heart of Little Beard's Town.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: The Scorched Earth
description: The 1994 collapse of the nearby old Retsof mine made the area's wells and waters toxic and turned some of its still amazingly fertile topsoil into this.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: Torches to Plough Shares
description: Ample farms now stand on the former fields and orchards of Little Beard's Town. This one borders on the Retsof sink hole, only yards from Boyd- Parker Park and in the shadow of the new American Salt Co. mine.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: Order of Battle
description: Outnumbering the population of Western Iroquoia, Sullivan's Army set out on a scorched earth invasion that burned all known villages and enlisted hunger by burning the harvest as winter approached.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: Tortured Tree
description: Distressed, this tree expires on the very site of the Boyd-Parker ambush by the Senecas, three days before Sullivan's burning of nearby Little Beard's Town, the Seneca capital and Western Door.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: Boyd-Parker Park 1
description: Set beside the Geneseo -Cuylerville Rd.(Rt. 39), this site and their Ambuscade are the only true Memorials to any named individuals, among the more than 10,000 fighters, victims and refugees directly involved in or impacted by the S-C Invasion.
curatorial_notes: The Onondaga capital, Onondaga Castle, was burnt on April 12-13, 1779. At Rt. 11, near Onondaga. The Seneca capital, Little Beard's Town, was burnt on Sept. 14-15, 1779. At Rt. 39, near Geneseo. The Cayuga capital, Goi-O-Guen, was burnt on Sept. 22-23, 1779. At Rt. 90, near Aurora. See its 1929 Redux, in the L. P. Hecht Gallery.

label: I'll Take Manhattan!
description: The iconic "sale" of Manhattan for $24 in trinkets, on the base of Henry Hudson's towering statue. Hudson Park, Riverdale, NYC.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Old Wine, New Bottle
description: Ancestral mound near Goi-O-Gouen, the former Cayuga capital, on private farmlands, behind an electric fence. Cayugas were burned out by Sullivan-Clinton on Sept. 14, 1779.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: "The White Woman, Mary Jemison"
description: Captured by Indians, the famed Scotch-Irish Jemison lived mostly as a Seneca, bearing two children. Her burial-site statue, at Letchworth Park, NY, would reclaim her as a Christian.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Indians Have Always Paid The Price
description: Jemison's mixed-media piece brings together past and present images of the domination of Indians in the Americas. What began with Columbus and continued with Sullivan-Clinton is carried through to today.

label: Gen. John Sullivan with Spear
description: Though he won with superior numbers and first use of field cannons against N. American Indians, the Victor is depicted with a spear.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Not One Inch...
description: One of scores of signs posted around the Cayuga Lake region by opponents of Cayuga land claims. Since S/C, the Cayugas lost their NY lands. But the court case continues... Though he won with superior numbers and first use of field cannons against N. American Indians, the Victor is depicted with a spear.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Stamped in History
description: Issued in 1929, the 150th Anniversary stamp joined the erection of over 55 highway markers and 35 stone memorials across NY State and many in Pennsylvania.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: General Sullivan's Slave House
description: Slaves quarters at the rear of Gen. Sullivan's home at Durham, New Hampshire. He, George Washington, Jeremiah Wadsworth and Philip Schuyler all held slaves.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Innovation
description: Facing Cayuga Lake is the former site of Goi-O-Gouen, the Cayuga capital. As Cols. Dear- born and Wm. Butler burned their west and east bank villages, the Cayugas hid in nearby Great Gully. They lost all their NY lands.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Big Tree Under Glass
description: The shed on the right harbors a section of the famed great oak tree (27' in diameter) who witnessed the signing away of Seneca lands at the Big Tree Conference in 1797. Swept away by a floodtide in 1857, a chunk now lies there, in Geneseo, under glass.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Rematch 1
description: In the 225th Anniversary year of Sullivan-Clinton, well-organized landholders group opposes any concessions to Cayuga land claims with scores of signs.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: For You, the Precious
description: Dutch trader shows all that glitters... New York's first big conver- sion experience adorns the base of Henry Hudson's statue in NYC.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Rematch 2
description: Fighting for the league Championship, another Battle of Newtown. This time it's just sports, just outside the Onondaga Nation Lacrosse/Hockey Arena.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Road to Tribes Hill
description: no caption
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Three Sisters
description: De-o-ha-ko, "the foods that sustain us." The 3 Sisters - corn, beans and squash - are the traditional heart of Iroquois survival and worldview. They were the prime targets of the Sullivan-Clinton Campaign.

label: End of the Trail?
description: A cul-de-sac in former Iroquois country, now called Tribes Hill, New York, in the Mohawk Valley.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: To The Tribe's Hill
description: What's in a name? Well, this sign points to a village named Tribes Hill, in the Mohawk Valley since 1713, on former Mohawk lands.
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Drive to Tribes Hill
description: no caption
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Thru Mohawk Valley
description: no caption
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Iroquois Trail Rd.
description: no caption
curatorial_notes: Alternative Viewpoints, from Here & There...

label: Commander-in- chief
description: George Washington as he looked in 1779, the year he launches the Sullivan- Clinton Campaign. Painted then by Charles Willson Peale. (Courtesy of the U.S. Senate.)
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: Cherry Valley!
description: Moment from the 225th Gala Reenactment of the 1778 Yankee defeat by English-Iroquois-Tory forces. Then termed a massacre, it became the pretext to invade what was Iroquois country.
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: Sullivan-Clinton Road Monument
description: Twenty-nine such highway markers were commissioned by New York State in 1929 (the 150th anniversary) to mark the 1779 invasion route.
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: Felled by Tomahawk
description: The town of Cherry Valley marks the site where Colonel Ichabod Alden, post commader, was killed in the Yankee defeat.
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: Signing Off
description: Re-enactors part ways after the 225th anniversary of the Cherry Valley Massacre.
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: La riposte de Piz'i (Chief Gall)
medium: Composite of straw, plastic, soil, and fabric bound by a proprietary weatherproof coating
description: In the courtyard of his house, Ousmane Sow produced The Battle of Little Big Horn, a series of 35 epic pieces. These were first exhibited in Dakar in January of 1999 and later that year in an outdoor Paris exhibition on the Pont des Arts. It featured all of his series of sculptures and was seen by over 3 million visitors. In July-October of 2003, some of these LBH sculptures were shown in New York City at the Whitney Museum, as part of a major exhbition called "The American Effect."

label: Cherry Valley Massacre Monument
description: Cemetery monument to settlers killed by Indian- English-Loyalist attack of November, 1778.
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: Gen. John Sullivan
description: Co-commander of the Campaign. He filed its Offical Report to Congress. Then became New Hampshire's first US Governor.
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: Forever Set in Stone
description: Several of the 29 NYS road markers carry site- specific information on their back sides. This one, in Aurora, notes the destruction of the Cayuga capital.
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: Gen. James Clinton
description: The co-Commander of the Campaign, brother of NY rebel governor George Clinton, and father of NY State Gov. DeWitt Clinton.
curatorial_notes: Traditional and Patriotic Images, from Then & Now...

label: Sign Language
description: Passersby know little to nothing of this fateful junction's continuing impact on New York's indigenous peoples.
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: Sullivan St. NYC
description: Named for General John Sullivan, the street starts at Washington Square Park, where this Sullivan/ Clinton cor- ner resides, hidden in plain sight.
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: Melting Point
description: Washington and Sulli- van blazed the way toward the Erie Canal which made Manhattan rich. The city fuses their names at Greenwich Village's famed Wash- ington Square Park.
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: End of the Trail?
description: Replica of James Earle Fraser's once famous sculpture, End of the Trail, modeled in 1894, commissioned in 1915. (Courtesy Clint Fisher)
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: Equus
description: "A horse, a horse, my kingdom for..." Free Indian life ended on the Southern Plains in 1874 when the Army killed their horses.
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: Once A Warrior
description: Fraser's End of the Trail statue was first modeled in 1894, within four years after the Wounded Knee Massacre of Ghost Dancers.
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: La riposte de Piz'i (Chief Gall)
medium: Composite of straw, plastic, soil, and fabric bound by a proprietary weatherproof coating
description: In the courtyard of his house, Ousmane Sow produced The Battle of Little Big Horn, a series of 35 epic pieces. These were first exhibited in Dakar in January of 1999 and later that year in an outdoor Paris exhibition on the Pont des Arts. It featured all of his series of sculptures and was seen by over 3 million visitors. In July-October of 2003, some of these LBH sculptures were shown in New York City at the Whitney Museum, as part of a major exhbition called "The American Effect."

label: Not At Liberty
description: Two national treasures in the dustbin of history.
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: Equestrian Moment
description: Lord of its domain. This in the storage area between the Brooklyn Museum and Botanical Gardens.
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: Stilled Life
description: Shards in the storage area between the Brooklyn Museum and Botanical Gardens (Spring, 2004)
curatorial_notes: Traces from New York & Other Metropolises...

label: Western Doorstep
description: The Genesee flows thru today' Letchworth State Park, "The Grand Canyon of the East," at the Western Door -- where the Scottish-born, Seneca-reared Mary Jemison lived, after S/C and the Winter of 1779. (Photo by Bill Hecht)
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: Survivors
current_location: Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division Washington, D.C. 20540 USA
description: The Haudenosaunee people during another winter (1914). Some are Senecas from the Cattaraugus reservation. Several may be from a touring company. The worst winter was 1779, when hundreds of refugees perished outside Ft. Niagara in Sullivan/ Clinton's wake. (Copyright, Wm. A. Drennan, Buffalo.)
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: At Wyalusing
description: "Warrior's Path" of Haudenosaunee trade, diplomacy and war linking NY and PA to VA and the Carolinas. Viewed from 500 ft. above the Susquehanna River, along Sullivan's route. (Kenn Anderson/ Canterbury Tours)
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: Cornplanter
description: Portrait of the great Seneca Chief by Fred. Bartoli, 1796. The original hangs behind the same glass with portraits of Red Jacket and Washington, as part of the Henry Luce III Collection at the New York Historical Society.
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: At The Unveiling
description: It's September 22, 1929, during Sullivan/Clin- ton's 150th Anniver- sary: Cayuga people with Chief Wilbur Shango tend a council fire at the official un- furling of a NYS road monument near Goi- O-Gouen, former Cayu- ga capital, above Auro- ra. Click 2 X: 1 X to expand, then again.
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: Red Jacket
description: 1820 portrait of the Seneca orator by J.L.D. Mathies. Freedom Medal denotes his accommo- dation to Yankee rule. He ended as a bulwark for Indian traditions vs. missionary incursions.
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: Growing Corn
description: The "Three Sisters" - corn, squash and beans - are at the heart of Haudenosaunee survi- val and worldview. Their destruction was an objective of Sullivan/ Clinton. While this 1508 village is Secotan, both peoples had advanced agrarian know-how. S/C officers' journals gush with surprise, before burning such towns.
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: Tazsunke Witko (Crazy Horse) est assailli
medium: Composite of straw, plastic, soil, and fabric bound by a proprietary weatherproof coating
description: In the courtyard of his house, Ousmane Sow produced The Battle of Little Big Horn, a series of 35 epic pieces. These were first exhibited in Dakar in January of 1999 and later that year in an outdoor Paris exhibition on the Pont des Arts. It featured all of his series of sculptures and was seen by over 3 million visitors. In July-October of 2003, some of these LBH sculptures were shown in New York City at the Whitney Museum, as part of a major exhbition called "The American Effect."

label: The Haudenosaunee!
description: Announcing the endur- ing presence and courage of the Haudeno- saunee people & Iroquois Confederacy today.
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: Tioga (Turning) Point
description: Where the Susquehanna and Chemung R's meet, this once Indian village of Teoga and neighbor -ing Queen Esther's Town (the "Southern Door"), were burned in revenge by the Hartley Expedition (1778). It was the meeting place of Sullivan & Clinton's armies & launch pad against Iroquoia.
curatorial_notes: Haudenosaunee Images, Yesterday & Today...

label: The Western Door
description: The Western Door Iroquoia's western door, where the Genesee River snakes on through what ranked atop North America's most fertile regions. It was Seneca country for hundreds of years, until September 1779 and the treaties that uprooted them. (Photo by B. Hecht)
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: The Three Sisters
description: Traditional Haudeno- saunee life is a spiritual bonding with mother earth. The 3 - corn, beans and squash - are central to physical and spiritual survival. They were targeted and burn- ed by the Sullivan/ Clinton Campaign.
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: The Warrior's Path
description: The Warrior's Path Sullivan's March looked upon the Susquehanna River, today among America's most toxic. It had been an Indian path of commerce, war and diplomacy. Its continu- ed cleanup would renew it as a path to wellness.
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: Rt. 17 Corn Field
description: NY's Southern Tier, formerly Iroquoia, is dotted with ample corn fields, echoing those reduced to scorched earth by Sullivan/ Clinton.
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: Longhouse
description: The Haudenosaunee are "people making a long- house." Spanning NY, Mohawks kept its Eas- tern Door, Onondagas kept (and keep) its cen- tral fire, and Senecas kept its Western Door. This stands at Ganonda- gan State Historic Site, Victor, NY.
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: Iroquoia 1779
description: Then, Sullivan/Clinton was a scorched earth campaign that smoked the Finger Lakes. Today, Global Warming is scorching the earth. Mother Earth summons us. (Photo- McCarthy)
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: Scorched Earth
description: Earth at the Western Door: the former Seneca capital Little Beard's Town, near Geneseo, NY. Burned by S/C in September 1779, the land was ruined by the Retsof Salt Mine collapse of 1994. Seeping meth- ane has imperiled the water table. And a new mine that threatened ancestral graves still dusts the fields.
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: Sacred & Imperiled
description: Lake Onondaga is the birthplace of the Hau- denosaunee Confeder- acy under the Peace- maker. It's contamina- ted, sits atop a sea of mercury, and stands at the cutting edge of to- day's struggle to re- store the environment and protect our health.
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: Corps a corps au couteau
medium: Composite of straw, plastic, soil, and fabric bound by a proprietary weatherproof coating
description: In the courtyard of his house, Ousmane Sow produced The Battle of Little Big Horn, a series of 35 epic pieces. These were first exhibited in Dakar in January of 1999 and later that year in an outdoor Paris exhibition on the Pont des Arts. It featured all of his series of sculptures and was seen by over 3 million visitors. In July-October of 2003, some of these LBH sculptures were shown in New York City at the Whitney Museum, as part of a major exhbition called "The American Effect."

label: Stewardship Now
description: An Onondaga chief, Brad Powless, gazes on toxic Onondaga Lake. A legal action affirms his nation's stewardship over the health of its traditional lands and urges much faster and responsible cleanup of the entire area's 70 superfund sites.
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: NOLA 2005
description: Since Hurricane Katrina's first day, NOLA's uprooted long-term residents were termed refugees. Iroquoia 1779 & NOLA 2005 share other com- monalities - like Lake Onondaga's mount- ing toxic crisis. Katrina hit on August 29; in 1779, that day saw the battle of Newtown, as Iroquoia was invaded by S/C.
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: As long as the Rivers flow
description: They continue to flow at NY's Ganondagan State Historic Site, restored as a center and seed-bed of traditional Haudenosau- nee culture, values and vision. (Photo by Geoff Harding)
curatorial_notes: Traditionally, the Haudenosaunee decide on actions taken today by their impact in seven generations. Humanity's survival depends on our embrace of their values...

label: Trailblazer, East
description: In 1774, Silas Deane backed annexing nor- thern PA to Litchfield County, CT, as the Town of Westmoreland. CT's projecting its "western claim" - through Hart- ford's Susquehanna Co. - was proof of "the Glory of this New World."
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: War Memorial
description: War Memorial Monument to the more than 400 Yankee soldiers and settlers slain in the July, 1778 attack on Wyoming Valley by Tory and Indian forces under John Butler and Sayenqueraghta.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: Tioga (Turning) Point
description: Tioga (Turning) Point The Indian villages of Teoga and its neighbor Queen Esther's Town (the "Southern Door"), were burned in revenge for Wyoming by the Hartley Expedition (1778). It became the meeting place (1779) of Sullivan & Clinton's armies and launching pad against Iroquoia.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: Susquehanna Banks
description: The river runs through and links NY and PA regions traversed by S/C. This island, near the Wyoming Battlesite, is deemed the birthplace of Hiawatha, the great Iroquois peace bringer.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: Over Ancestral Bones
description: Plaque at the Wyoming Monument commemo- rates the Yankee fallen, 80 of whose remains lie beneath, and are memo- rialized every July 4th, Independence Day.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: Wyoming!
description: Avenging the July, 1778 blood shed in the Wyoming Valley became the main rallying point, across the rebelling colonies, for launching the Sulli- van-Clinton Campaign.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.

label: Marking Wyoming
description: Wyoming's stature in the American Revolu- tion is reflected by the battle being registered as a National Historic Site.
curatorial_notes: The pretext and 1/2 of the build-up, march and launch of Sullivan/Clinton all happened in Pennsylvania.
